Award.AwardTitle: Research Initiation: Measuring mental demand of interactive textbooks using wearables and web analytics

Division.LongName: Div Of Engineering Education and Centers

Award.AbstractNarration:
Interactive textbooks have created a new web-based form of active learning. Students participating in these multi-sensory, interactive experiences may be learning faster or easier compared to traditional static textbooks. In this project, we will collect data on students' mental demand using non-invasive wearable wristbands as they "read" interactive web-based textbooks called zyBooks. Better understanding of students' mental demand in response to different elements of the textbooks could then inform the design of future instructional materials. The measurement platform developed for this study could also be used outside classroom settings, including study groups and organized events such as Hackathons. Therefore, the proposed research has the potential to significantly advance our understanding about formation of engineers through the acquisition of technical and professional skills and knowledge in both formal and informal settings.

Interactive textbooks, such as zyBooks, have been found to have much higher reading rates than traditional textbooks, and their reading rates have also been found to be correlated with course grades. However, it is difficult to ascertain which components of an interactive textbook are driving the increased reading rates. The proposed research targets this problem by providing a platform for continuous measurement of mental demand as students engage with an interactive textbook through reading, watching animations, and interactive problem solving. This project will collect physiological data on students using non-invasive wearable wristbands and synchronize this data with web-based interaction data from zyBooks. The research team will first collect data in a controlled laboratory setting where students will partake in a set of reading and problem solving tasks, and then they will self report their mental demand using the NASA Task Load Index. Using features extracted from the two data streams, the research team will train a machine learning algorithm to predict the student's self-reported mental demand. In phase 2 of the study, the team will collect data on students studying in their natural, everyday study settings and use the trained machine learning algorithm to predict the students' mental demand, which will result in a continuous measurement of students' mental demand as they progress through different animations, activities, and exercises in the zyBook. The measurement platform will provide a first step towards the use of wearables to transform teaching and learning and can be used to explore additional pedagogical questions.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project examined how students engaged with interactive, web-based textbooks, particularly zyBooks, using wearable devices to measure mental demand. Interactive textbooks offer dynamic, multi-sensory learning experiences that differ from traditional static materials. This study built on prior findings that linked higher engagement rates with improved course performance, focusing on how animations that replace static figures or text may enhance learning.

 

The research team analyzed big data generated from the interactive textbooks, specifically student interaction with animations. Over 60,000 animation views across 140+ unique animations in a chemical engineering course were evaluated. Variations in animation usage, completion, and view times were tracked across five cohorts. Key findings revealed that animation views exceeded 100% for all chapters. Also, median view times ranged from 22 seconds for simpler animations to 59 seconds for complex ones. Animations involving derivations showed the longest viewing times, while physical-world animations had the shortest, reflecting differences in cognitive engagement.

 

In another part of this project, physiological data from wearable wristbands were synchronized with interaction data, such as click streams, to train a machine learning algorithm to predict students' mental demand during textbook use. Initial data collection occurred in a controlled laboratory environment, where students completed reading and problem-solving tasks. Their mental demand was measured using wearable metrics validated by self-reported NASA Task Load Index (TLX) data. We built a machine learning algorithm to predict the mental demand TLX score reported by a subject during a task and found that the mental demand TLX scores of the subjects can be predicted somewhat accurately, with an R2 relative error measure in the range of 0.3-0.4, which is quite typical for human subject studies using wearables. We also found that both the skin conductance data collected using the wearable and click stream data collected from the interactive textbook are necessary to produce this level of accuracy. Furthermore, the predicted mental demand over time was found to vary significantly throughout an animation, with minute-by-minute predicted values varying by 2-6 on the 0-20 TLX scale, depending on the subject. This highlights one of the limitations of the correct “gold standard” approach of using self-reported mental demand scores, which represent an aggregate view of an entire task, while our machine learning-based approach using physiological and click stream data can be used to measure variations in mental demand during a task.

 

Despite initial delays due to human-subjects research protocols, the project aimed to inform future instructional material design by tailoring resources to cognitive needs. This work represents a step toward leveraging wearable technology to advance teaching practices and explore broader questions in engineering education.
